content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="0.5 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on a horizontal surface is attached to a horizontal spring of negligible mass and spring constant <math alttext="50 newtons per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N/m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The other end of the spring is attached to a wall, and there is negligible friction between the block and the horizontal surface. When the spring is unstretched, the block is located at <math alttext="x equals 0 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is then pulled to <math alttext="x equals 0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and released from rest so that the block-spring system oscillates between <math alttext="x equals negative 0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure. Which of the following claims is correct about the block’s period of oscillation?

choices.label: The period would increase if the block were released from rest at <math alttext="x equals 0.8 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The period would increase if the block had a mass of <math alttext="1.2 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The period would increase if the spring had a spring constant of <math alttext="75 newtons per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N/m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The period would increase if the block-spring system was oriented vertically so that the block-spring system oscillates between <math alttext="y equals negative 0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y equals 0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mass of the block is <math alttext="0.5 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the spring constant is <math alttext="50 newtons per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N/m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The period would increase if the block had a mass of <math alttext="1.2 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
